questions.text: Among the following all are the good prognostic factors for Schizophrenia except
questions.solution:
Good prognostic factors for Schizophrenia are:

  • Acute or abrupt onset
  • Onset after 35 yrs of age
  • Presence of precipitating stressor
  • Short duration (<6 months)
  • Presence of depression
  • Predominance of positive symptoms
  • Family history of mood disorders
  • Female sex
  • Good social support
  • Presence of confusion, perplexity or disorientation
  • Proper treatment
  • Normal cranial CT

questions.text: A 14 year old student was diagnosed with schizophrenia. He was started on risperidone. The patient is responding well. The duration of treatment will be
questions.solution:
The treatment of schizophrenia is generally continued for 2 years after the first episode.

Duration of treatment: Duration of treatment depends on a number of factors and will need to be individualized. The suggested guidelines are as follows:

  • First-episode patients ought to receive 1-2 years of maintenance treatment
  • Patients with several episodes or exacerbations are to receive maintenance treatment for 5 years or longer after the last episode
  • Patients with history of aggression or suicide attempts should receive treatment for longer period or lifelong.

  • The most appropriate treatment of this condition is addition of beta blocker (Propranolol)

questions.text: The toxic level of lithium in plasma is
questions.solution:
Levels of lithium in the body

  • Thrapeutic levels: 0.6-1.2mEq/L
  • Prophylactic levels: for the prevention of relapse 0.6-1 mEq/L
  • Toxic lithium levels: > 2.0 mEq/L

Note: While haemodialysis is considered when serum lithium level is 4.0mEq/L and above, signs of lithium toxicity usually start showing when the serum level is > 2.0mEq/L. One should not get confused between the two.

questions.text: A teenage girl was repeatedly sexually abused by her alcoholic family friend. He threatened her of sexual abuse on her sibling if she told anyone about the abuse. The girl became suicidal but felt that she had to stay alive to protect her siblings. So she ran away from home and got into the bus. After 6 hours of journey when the police stopped her and asked her whereabouts she did not remember where she had come from or she could not recall the events. What would be your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above situation describes the presence of traumatic event following which she travels to a new place and forgets her initial identity which is known as dissociative fugue.

  • According to DSM-5, dissociative fugue is now a specifier of dissociative amnesia rather than a separate diagnosis.
  • Dissociative fugue is characterized by episodes of wandering away. During the episode, the person usually adopts a new identity with complete amnesia of earlier life
  • The onset is usually sudden, often in the presence of severe stress

questions.text: A 27 year old woman has nightmare from which she suddenly wakes up. She has frequent flashbacks about the accident where she lost her husband 4 months back and avoids recollecting it. This is
questions.solution:
The above scenario depicted is Post traumatic stress disorder

This disorder arises as a delayed reaction to a catastrophic life event which is likely to cause pervasive distress in almost any person

It develops after a period of latency and usually within 6 months of the event

It is characterized by flashback or nightmares of the event with hyper arousal and avoidance of recalling the events

Acute stress reaction is the reaction that develops on 2nd or 3rd day of stressful event

The above condition is hypochondriasis.

  • Hypochondriasis is defined as persistent preoccupation with a fear or belief of having a serious disease, based on person’s own interpretation about the body function.
  • They are reluctant to believe that their body is normal even after investigations show normal report.

Note: Patients with somatisation disorder, come to the doctor with multiple symptoms where as in hypochondriasis they come with the diagnosis i.e disease.

questions.solution:
Autism is also called as autistic disorder, pervasive development disorder, childhood autism.

It is commonly in males and typically appears before the age of 2 1/2 years

The characteristic clinical features are

  • Impairment in the reciprocal social and interpersonal interaction
    • Absent social smile
    • Lack of eye to eye contact
    • Lack of awareness to others and lack of attachment to parents
    • No or abnormal social play
    • Marked impairment in making friends
  • Impairment in language and non verbal communication
    • Lack of verbal or facial response to sounds or voices
    • Absence of communicative sounds like babbling in infancy
    • Absent or delayed speech
    • Presence of echolalia, perseveration
  • Abnormal behavior characteristics
    • Mannerisms
    • Stereotyped behaviours such as head banging, body spinning, hand flicking, lining up objects
    • Ritualistic and compulsive behavior
  • A large majority of these children have moderate to profound mental retardation
  • Majority of these children enjoy music

questions.text: A school teacher finds a 7 yr old child to be extremely naughty, unable to sit in a place for a long time, excessively talking, and unable to concentrate on a thing for a long time. Which of the following drug is used in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder(ADHD). The drug of choice for ADHD is Methylphenidate.

Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is a neuro­ psychiatric condition characterized by a pattern of diminished attention span and increased impulsivity or hyperactivity. The prefrontal cortex of the brain has been implicated in its etiology and dopamine is the main neurotransmitter. 

ADHD can begin during infancy but is usually rec­ognized between 1-3 years of age. ADHD was known as minimal brain dysfunction earlier. The characteristics of children with ADHD, in order of frequency, are

  • Hyperactivity
  • Attention deficit (short attention span, distractibility)
  • Impulsivity (action before thought, abrupt shifts in activity, lack of organization)
  • Memory and thinking deficits
  • Specific learning disabilities
  • Speech and hearing deficits.

Under DSM-5 criteria, for diagnosis of ADHD, it is necessary for symptoms to be present prior to age 12, persist for at least 6 months, have a negative impact on social, academic, or occupational activities, and be present in two or more settings.

The course of ADHD is variable. The majority of the cases persist into adult life. The hyperactivity may sometimes disappear, but the decreased attention span and impulse-control problems usually persist. Patients with ADHD are vulnerable to antisocial behavior, conduct disorder, substance use disorders, and mood disorders.

Pharmacotherapy is the first line of treatment for ADHD. CNS stimulants are the first-choice agents as they have shown the greatest efficacy with mild tolerable side effects. The CNS stimulants used are dopamine agonists like methylphenidate, amphetamine salts, and dextroamphetamine. Non-stimulant medications used in the treatment of ADHD include atomoxetine (norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor), clonidine, and guanfacine (Alpha agonists).

Psychosocial interventions such as academic organization skills remediation, parent training, behavior modification in the classroom and at home, cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), and social skills training are also used as an adjunct to pharmacotherapy.

Note: Modafinil is used in the management of narcolepsy.

questions.text: Nocturnal enuresis is diagnosed in child after what age
questions.solution:
• Nocturnal enuresis is involuntary urination that happens at night while sleeping
  • More than 85% of children attain both diurnal and nocturnal control of bladder by 5 yrs of age
  • If the nocturnal control of bladder doesn’t appear even after 5yrs of age this is known as nocturnal enuresis
  • Most important etiology of nocturnal enuresis is developmental delay
  • Treatment involves behavioral modification like encouraging voluntary voiding of urine before sleeping
  • Restricting intake of fluids after 8 pm
  • Alarm therapy:
    • Alarm consists of small sensor attached to the child’s underwear or mat under the bedsheet When the child starts wetting the bed the sensors are activated causing the alarm to ring
  • If the enuresis persists despite the above interventions then imipramine , oxybutynin, desmopressin or tolterodine can be used

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic who hadn’t consumed alcohol for the past 3 days was brought to the emergency department. He had features of disorientation, poor attention span, and agitation. On examination, he had fever, tachycardia, and diaphoresis. Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of disorientation with features of autonomic hyperactivity (tachycardia, diaphoresis, fever) in a patient who stopped alcohol 3 days back is suggestive of delirium tremens.

Delirium tremens is the most severe alcohol withdrawal syndrome. It occurs usually within 3-4 days of alcohol withdrawal.

Characteristic features are:

  • Clouding of consciousness with disorientation to time and place
  • Poor attention and distractibility
  • Visual hallucination and illusions which are often vivid and frightening
  • Autonomic disturbances like tachycardia, fever, hypertension, sweating, and pupillary dilatation
  • Psychomotor agitation and ataxia

Benzodiazepines such as chlordiazepoxide and lorazepam are used in the treatment and prevention of delirium tremens.

Option A: Korsakoffs psychosis is characterized by impaired mental abilities (especially recent memory) and anterograde amnesia in an alert and responsive patient. The patient may have symptoms of confabulation.

Option B: Wernicke's encephalopathy is characterized by ataxia (affecting primarily the gait), vestibular dysfunction, confusion, and ocular motility abnormalities.

Option D: Alcohol-induced dementia is characterized by the development of multiple cognitive deficits (e.g., memory problems, language impairment, and an inability to perform complex motor tasks) that are judged to be a direct consequence of alcohol use. This persists beyond the usual duration of alcohol intoxication or acute withdrawal.

A recent study found that even moderate alcohol consumption reduces grey matter, up to 0.8% of the volume reduction, more than any other modifiable risk factor including smoking.

questions.text: The patient with schizophrenia has marked thought disorder, emotional disturbance and loosening of association. What is the type of schizophrenia?
questions.solution:
Types of Schizophrenia

Paranoid Schizophrenia: In addition to the general symptoms of schizophrenia they have delusions of persecution, reference, grandeur, control, or infidelity

  • Disorganized schizophrenia: It is characterized by
    • Marked thought disorder, incoherence, and severe loosening of association
    • Emotional disturbances like inappropriate affect, blunted affect or senseless giggling, mirror-gazing for long period, and markedly impaired social and occupational functioning.
  • Catatonic Schizophrenia: it has two subtypes
    • Excited catatonia characterized by increase psychomotor activity and increased speech production
    • Stuporous catatonia characterized by mutism with akinesis (stupor), echolalia, echopraxia, and waxy flexibility
  • Simple schizophrenia with early-onset and characteristic presence of negative symptoms
  • Latent Schizophrenia: This is diagnosed after an episode of schizophrenia has occurred. There is an absence of florid psychotic symptoms such as delusion and hallucinations.
  • Undifferentiated schizophrenia: symptoms which cannot be categorized into any of the types

questions.text: Which among the following is not an indication for the use of electroconvulsive therapy (ECT)?
questions.solution:
Indications of ECT:

Diagnostic indications - 

  • Major depression (Bipolar and unipolar)
  • Psychotic depression (Option A)
  • Mania
  • Acute exacerbation of schizophrenia
  • Catatonic schizophrenia
  • Schizoaffective disorder (Option D)
  • Parkinson's disease (Option C)
  • Neuroleptic malignant disorder

Panic disorder is not an indication of the use of electroconvulsive therapy. 

Clinical indications - 

  • Primary - 
    • When rapid response is required
    • When the risk of other treatment modalities outweighs the benefits
    • Poor response to previous antipsychotic therapy
    • Good response to previous ECT therapy
    • Preference of patient
  • Secondary - 
    • Poor response or failure to respond to pharmacotherapy in the current episode
    • Rapid definitive response necessitated by the deterioration of the patient's condition

Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) is not effective in somatization disorder (unless accompanied by depression), personality disorders, and anxiety disorders such as panic disorder.

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for the setting of the personal goals and aspiration in human beings
questions.solution:
Structural theory of mind was given by Sigmund Freud. He divided the mental apparatus into three distinct structures

  • Id : it contains basic drives and instincts and works on the basis of pleasure principle
  • Ego: it is determined by the experience of reality and hence works on the basis of reality principle
  • Super ego: it is influenced by the family members, religion and important people n the surrounding environment
    • It has a component known as ego ideal which is responsible for setting the personal goal and ambitions

questions.text: An IT employee, who is frustrated by his boss, shows anger on his wife even for the small things. This defense mechanism is known as
questions.solution:
The term ego defense mechanism refers to the automatic, involuntary and unconsciously instituted psychological activity by which the unacceptable urges or impulses are excluded from the conscious awareness.

Some of the defense mechanisms

  • Displacement: Unconscious shifting of emotions, usually aroused by perceived threat, from an unconscious impulse to less threatening external object which is then thought to be a source of threat
  • Projection: Unconscious attribution of ones own attitude and urges to other person
  • Eg: Blaming others for the mistake done by self
  • Reaction formation: Unconscious transformation of unacceptable impulses into exactly opposite attitudes, impulses, feelings or behaviors.
  • Eg: Lustful man to hide his feelings shows disgust on seeing woman
  • Splitting: Unconscious viewing of self or others as good or bad without considering whole range of qualities

questions.text: Narcolepsy is characterized by all except

questions.text: A patient is scared of heights, first the doctor asks him to imagine that he is on terrace. When the patient starts feeling anxious then doctor asks him to relax. The next session is followed by imagining that he is standing on a 12 storey building followed by relaxation and then at the top of the hill. This technique is called as
questions.solution:
Systematic desensitization technique is based on the principle of reciprocal inhibition which states that if a response incompatible with anxiety is made to occur at the same time as an anxiety provoking stimulus, anxiety is reduced by reciprocal inhibition

Steps:

  • Relaxation training
  • Hierarchy construction: the patient is asked to list all the conditions provoking anxiety and then rearrange in descending order of anxiety provocation.
  • Relaxation proper: This can be done either in imagery or in reality. At first the lowest item in hierarchy is confronted. When the patient becomes anxious doctor asks him to relax. Then the next item in hierarchy is confronted followed by relaxation technique. After few sessions patient is able to control his anxiety.

  • Hypnosis
